values.alignmentText: Tropical forests, coral reefs, and national parks offer rich biodiversity amid urban sprawl.
Low-lying coasts and hotter seasons make climate change a serious threat despite adaptation efforts.
Hot, humid tropics with a rainy monsoon and short cool season, far from our mild preference.
Bangkok often suffers from PM2.5 pollution though smaller towns fare better.
Seasonal flooding and occasional typhoons pose recurring hazards.
26–34°C (79–93°F) hot and dry before the monsoon.
25–32°C (77–90°F) with heavy rain and high humidity.
24–31°C (75–88°F) still humid but rains taper.
22–32°C (72–90°F) drier and slightly cooler.
Islands like Phuket and Samui offer warm beaches and resort infrastructure.
Seas stay around 27–30°C (81–86°F) year-round.
Karst mountains, jungles, and temples provide striking scenery.
Daily minimum varies by province around 363 THB (~$10) offering a low baseline.
Bangkok developers earn roughly $20k–$40k USD, stretching further with low costs.
Multinational firms and outsourcing shops use .NET but the ecosystem is modest.
Ruby jobs are scarce, mainly in startups.
Non-B work visas require employer sponsorship and proof of capital.
Tourism and manufacturing keep GDP growing though inequality persists.
Co-working hubs and nomad visas support remote work, especially in Bangkok and Chiang Mai.
Thai offices can run long hours yet overall culture values leisure and festivals.
Labor law caps at 48 but many firms keep near 40.
Only 6 paid days after a year, among the region’s lowest.
Multinationals offer 10–15 days and taking them is usually accepted.
Relaxed vibe outside Bangkok suits a slower lifestyle.
School and work often start around 8 a.m., with evening markets or family dinners.
Weekends feature temple visits, outdoor markets, or beach trips.
Extended families are common and children are welcomed in public spaces.
No legal recognition and social norms favor monogamy.
Society expects respectful, well-behaved kids; communal caretaking is normal.
Urban parks and malls cater to families though sidewalks can be rough.
Public schools are basic; international schools provide quality at high cost.
Private nurseries and preschool programs are available but quality varies.
Government subsidies are limited, leaving families to self-fund.
Foreign families receive no subsidies but can access private centers.
Universal basic education through grade 9 with mixed outcomes.
Public schools accept foreign kids but language barriers and quality pose issues.
International schools deliver high standards yet tuition is steep.
Small child allowances and maternity leave exist but benefits are modest.
Most benefits exclude foreigners aside from private insurance options.
Public universities are affordable and improving.
Foreign students pay higher tuition but admissions are possible.
Traditional roles persist though urban areas show more equality.
Thai culture shows visible gender variance, especially kathoey communities.
Legal protections against discrimination remain limited.
Femininity is associated with modesty and soft-spoken behavior.
Men face expectations to provide and maintain a calm demeanor.
Blend of Buddhist culture, street food, and digital nomad scene draws interest.
Tourist zones use English but proficiency drops outside cities.
Social views are moderate with some reforms but conservative institutions.
Marxism holds little sway beyond academic circles.
Buddhist majority allows private disbelief but few identify openly.
Sex work is widespread yet public conversation remains modest.
Public tolerance in urban areas contrasts with lack of legal rights.
Friendly smiles and neighborhood markets foster community.
Pride in hospitality and cultural heritage.
Generally cordial toward ASEAN neighbors but wary of Myanmar’s instability.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Seen as a tourist magnet and pragmatic partner.
Vibrant scenes from Bangkok clubs to beach parties.
Casual lightweight clothing suits the heat; business wear mostly in offices.
Blend of modest outfits and trendy street fashion.
Cooking classes, Muay Thai, and temple festivals are popular.
Growing café scene in Bangkok and Chiang Mai.
Live music bars and EDM festivals abound.
Expat and tech meetups flourish in urban hubs.
Easy access to jungles, mountains, and marine parks.
Constitutional monarchy with frequent military influence.
Buddhism informs culture yet the state is officially secular.
Labor unions exist but power is limited and enforcement inconsistent.
Nationalism and royalism dominate official narratives.
Military coups and party bans keep democracy fragile.
Market-driven economy with a significant informal sector.
Political protests recur but daily life remains mostly stable.
Government controls messaging around monarchy and security.
Emphasis on royal loyalty and national unity.
Basic welfare programs exist but coverage is patchy.
Many residents distrust politicians due to corruption scandals.
Bribery and patronage are commonly perceived.
Petty bribery in bureaucracy alongside high-level kickbacks.
Affordable rentals available but quality varies; expats cluster in condos.
Violent crime is low but petty theft and scams affect tourists.
Universal Coverage Scheme provides basic care with long waits.
Expats rely on private hospitals offering high-quality care at moderate prices.
Limited public subsidies mean families often rely on relatives.
Policies support nuclear families modestly with maternity leave and education subsidies.
Public education quality varies; strong private and international options exist.
Bangkok's BTS/MRT and regional buses provide coverage but rural areas rely on cars.
Mixed economy with strong tourism and manufacturing sectors.
Progressive income tax filed annually; VAT collected at point of sale.
With moderate incomes, effective income tax likely around 15%.
Modern banking apps and QR payments are widely adopted.
Low costs for food and housing stretch budgets.
State pension exists but payouts are small.
Long-stay retirement visas and affordable healthcare make retirement feasible.
Tourist, Non-B, marriage, and Elite visas offer varied routes but paperwork is heavy.
Friendly to Westerners though long-term residency requires patience.
One-year extensions or elite packages; permanent residency after years.
Naturalization demands years of residence, language, and quotas.
Spouses and kids can be included on dependent visas.
Processing takes months; elite visa fees reach tens of thousands USD.
Strict reporting and overstay fines require diligence.
Thai-born can hold dual; naturalized citizens are expected to renounce.
Regular 90-day reports and address checks can be bureaucratic.
Growing indie scene and outsourcing companies but limited AAA presence.
Studios like Sanuk Games and Urnique produce regional titles.
Events in Bangkok and Chiang Mai foster small dev communities.
Low living costs and emerging talent make a feasible launchpad.
High-speed internet and modern malls coexist with patchy rural infrastructure.
